newsitem.title: CHILE: German fugitive sighting said to be obvious ploy.
newsitem.headline: German fugitive sighting said to be obvious ploy.

text.p: The fugitive leader of a secretive German colony in southern Chile made a clumsy attempt over the weekend to throw authorities off his trail by arranging for someone to surface in Argentina under his name, officials said on Monday.

Interior Minister Carlos Figueroa said the episode in the Argentine ski resort of Bariloche, in which a man calling himself Schaefer checked into a posh hotel but fled through a window when police knocked on his door, was an obvious diversionary ploy.

"Here is a man who has an international arrest warrant out for him, and he would have us believe that he checked into a hotel with his real name and his real document number? They must think we're a bunch of incompetents to fall for that," said Interior Minister Carlos Figueroa.
"It seems to me an absolutely obvious diversionary tactic," he told reporters.

The man calling himself Schaefer, a former Nazi army corporal wanted on charges of molesting boys at the German enclave of Colonia Dignidad (Dignity Colony), checked into the hotel on Friday but fled through a second-floor window when police, alerted by an anonymous phone call, came knocking on his door.
All the police found inside the room was the man's pajamas.
The mysterious episode -- front-page news in Chile on Monday -- suggested Schaefer had fled over the Andes into Argentina but Chilean authorities said it was an obvious red herring.
Figueroa's deputy Belisario Velasco said on Sunday that the man who checked into the Bariloche hotel was taller and heavier than descriptions of the real Schaefer.
"The characteristics of the person in question don't match those of Paul Schaefer," said Velasco on local television.

He said authorities were not sure if Schaefer was still in Chile but that Colonia Dignidad, nestled among the Andean foothills near the town of Parral, "has thousands of hectares (acres) of forests and rivers, as well as tunnels and bunkers" where Schaefer could hide.

Schaefer, who has not been seen in public in recent years, faces charges of sexually molesting at least five Chilean boys who attended a boarding school at Colonia Dignidad. He and other leaders of the colony, founded by Schaefer in 1961, face various other charges including illegal detention of children and obstruction of justice.
He came to Chile sometime in the late 1950s fleeing charges of molesting boys at an orphanage he founded in Germany.

Chilean police, acting on a judge's search warrant, have made a series of inspections at the German settlement since mid-May but say they found no obvious sign of Schaefer. Four other leaders, two of them German citizens, have been arrested recently and released on bail.
